title-group.article-title: Acceleration harmonic identification for an electro-hydraulic servo shaking table based on the normalized least-mean-square adaptive algorithm

abstract.p: For an electro-hydraulic servo shaking table, there are nonlinearities, which cause acceleration harmonic distortion when they corresponds to a sine acceleration excitation signal. The work here is to develop an acceleration harmonic identification algorithm by using the normalized least-mean-square (LMS) adaptive algorithm, whose weights are updated by the error between the acceleration response and the estimated acceleration signal. The input vector is generated by the reference harmonics and the 90∘ phase shift. When the identification algorithm converges, the amplitude and phase of each harmonic can be computed from the weight vector. Experimental results show that the proposed harmonic identification has good real-time performance and a fast convergence rate, and it can identify harmonics on-line with high precision both in amplitude and in phase.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The shaking table is an important device to simulate the mechanical environment, and thus to measure the reliability under vibration condition for a specimen (Yao, 2007). It can be driven by hydraulic power, pneumatic power, electro-motion and even magnetostriction, and has been widely applied in many main industrial fields, such as aerospace, the nuclear industry, automobile and civil engineering, as described by Yao et al. (2011). Tagawa and Kajiwara (2007) described a large-scale electro-hydraulic shaking table in the National Research Institute for Earth Science and Disaster Prevention. The table was attached to five actuators in each horizontal direction and was supported by 14 actuators installed vertically underneath. The table is 20 m by 15 m in the plane dimension, and can accommodate specimens up to a weight of 1200 tones. Gong and Zhang (2008) studied a type of redundant actuation shaking table with eight identical limbs connecting the moving platform to the stationary platform, and presented a six-DOF (degree of freedom) shaking table by using a parallel mechanism with six sub-chains actuated by servo motors. Guan (2007) carried out research onathree-axis six-DOF shaking table with eight hydraulic actuators. Ammanagi et al. (2006) developed an eight-actuator shake table that includes single-ended actuator assemblies, contamination-insensitive servo-hydraulics and a robust digital signal processor (DSP)-based control and data acquisition system.

A shaking table test is used to evaluate the performance characteristics of scaled model structures subjected to base excitation. Kai and Kajiwara (2011) studied the dynamic response characteristics of human body using the shaking table test of crash test dummies. A series of full-scale tests was conducted on the E-Defense shaking table facilities in Japan to simulate various levels of realistic seismic damage in a high-rise structural steel building (Ji et al., 2011). The applicability of different pushover methods was analyzed on the example of a bridge, which was experimentally tested on three shake tables at the University of Nevada, Reno (Isakovic and Fischinger, 2011). Choi et al. (2011) carried out a series of shaking table tests on indirect–direct integrated health monitoring of pile foundations for the purpose of detecting global and local damage during their service life by simulating different damage conditions of pile foundations. Two 1/5-scaled models of nonseismic-designed wall-type structures were constructed by Park et al. (2011) and tested on a shaking table to evaluate their seismic performances. In order to study the dynamic interaction of substation equipment interconnected by flexible buses subjected to earthquakes, Xie and Wang (2011) carried out a shake table test on a full-scale model. Zhou and Lu (2004) took a shaking table test on a three-story one-bay steel frame model with metallic yield dampers, and their parallel connection with oil dampers, to study the dynamic characteristics and seismic performance of the energy dissipation system.

The shaking table here is driven by hydraulic power. For an electro-hydraulic servo system, which includes mechanical and electronic systems, there are various nonlinearities, such as the dead zone, friction, backlash, and so on (Yao et al., 2008). What is more, an electro-hydraulic servo system also has a large extent of model uncertainties, such as the external disturbances and leakage, which cannot be modeled exactly, and the nonlinear functions that describe them may not be known. The dynamic performance of a servo valve is influenced somewhat by operating conditions, such as supply pressure, input signal level, fluid and ambient temperature, and so on (Yao et al., 2010). Because of those nonlinear phenomenon, the acceleration output of an electro-hydraulic servo shaking table corresponding to a sinusoidal input contains harmonics with frequencies that are integer multiples of the fundamental frequency besides the fundamental, causing the acceleration harmonic distortion.

The acceleration harmonic imposes difficult control challenges of the electro-hydraulic servo shaking table. To cancel the acceleration harmonic for the electro-hydraulic servo shaking table and to improve its control performance, one needs to analyze the harmonic characteristics in real time, so it is necessary to develop a harmonic identification algorithm. However, nearly all researches on harmonic estimation are focused on power systems. Because artificial intelligent based on pattern recognition techniques is considered one of the dependable methods that can effectively realize highly nonlinear functions, Almaita and Asumadu (2011) used a radial basis function neural network to dynamically identify and estimate the fundamental, fifth harmonic and seventh harmonic components in converter waveforms. Sahoo et al. (2009) proposed a hybrid approach to estimate the amplitudes and phases of the fundamental, third and fifth harmonics of three different types of distorted power signals in the presence of white noise. In the scheme, a robust estimator, H∞ filter, was used for amplitude estimation, which was based upon state space modeling of the signals, and an adaptive linear combiner based on the neural network was used for phase estimation. Abniki et al., (2010) employed a variable window length algorithm for signal estimation, which is extended through time passing, and uses only post-fault data for signal estimation for the second harmonic estimation of the transformer differential protection in order to reduce the blocking time of the transformer in the inrush condition. Ren and Kezunovic (2010) proposed a method based on recursive wavelet transform and used the wavelet transform coefficients of voltage and current signals to estimate frequency and harmonic parameters in power systems. Chen and Chang (2009) used Prony's method for the time-varying power system harmonic estimation.

For an electro-hydraulic servo shaking table, which is a complex control system, because it needs to deal with many signals, such as oil pressure, displacement, velocity and acceleration, as well as the control scheme, the harmonic estimation method should be simple and easy to realize without computation burden so that it can identify the acceleration harmonics on-line in real time. The harmonic estimation algorithm applied in the power system usually cannot be directly adopted for an electro-hydraulic servo shaking table, because of its computation burden and complex structure. Yao et al. (2009) applied an Adaline neural network to identify the amplitudes and phase of harmonics on-line, as well as the fundamental acceleration output for an electro-hydraulic servo system. However, the developed algorithm may suffer from a problem of gradient noise amplification, and the step size influences the convergence rate and the stability. In addition, the initial values of the weights have great impact on the convergence rate.

Based on the normalized least-mean-square (LMS) adaptive algorithm, an acceleration harmonic identification algorithm is developed. Its weights are adjusted according to the error between the actual acceleration response and the estimated acceleration signal, which is the product of the weight vector and the input vector generated by the reference harmonics. The amplitude and phase of each harmonic is calculated from the weight vector.

sec.title: 2. System description
sec.p:
The electro-hydraulic servo shaking table here, as shown in Figure 1, is a single-DOF shaking table, which is driven by a symmetric cylinder controlled by a two-stage symmetric servo valve. The system parameters are shown in Table 1. A three-variable controller is applied to extend the system acceleration frequency bandwidth (Yao et al., 2010). The whole control system is shown in Figure 2. It is a host-target style control system. The host computer, which is a commercial personal computer (PC) that operates under Windows XP, serves as the user interface and allows the user to generate the command signal, observe the system state and data, control the system Start/Stop sequences, and so on. The target computer is an industrial computer, which includes acquisition boards, such as analog-to-digital (A/D), digital-to-analog (D/A) and digital input/output (I/O) boards. The real-time control algorithm, including the three-variable control, is operated on the target computer. Figure 1.

For a sine vibration test on an electro-hydraulic servo shaking table, the total harmonic distortion (THD) is a very important criterion to evaluate its waveform performance. Harmonic distortion is a relative measure of the amplitudes of the harmonics as compared to the amplitude of the fundamental. If the amplitude of the fundamental is A1 and the amplitudes of the harmonic are A2 (second harmonic), A3 (third harmonic), and so on, then the THD is given by (Yao et al., 2009) (1)THD=A22+A32+A42+…A1·100%

When the input signal is 3sin(2π×5t)m/s2, the acceleration response is as shown in Figure 3, from which it can be seen that the acceleration response is distorted by higher harmonics including the second, third, fourth, fifth and sixth harmonics. sec.title: 3. Least-mean-square adaptive algorithm
sec.p:
Widrow and Hoff developed the LMS adaptive algorithm in 1960. Because of its computational simplicity and excellent tracking for nonstationary environments, it has been widely applied in many fields, such as system identification, data analysis, noise cancellation, image processing, speech processing, control systems, and so on. The LMS adaptive algorithm can be written as (Yao et al., 2008, 2009) (2)g{y(k)=wT(k)x(k)e(k)=d(k)-y(k)w(k+1)=w(k)+μx(k)e(k)g. where d(k) is the desired signal, y(k) is the estimated output, e(k) is the error signal, w(k) is the weight vector, w(k)=[w1(k)w2(k)…wn(k)]T and x(k) is the input vector, x(k)=[x1(k)x2(k)…xn(k)]T. μ is the step size that regulates the speed and stability of theadaptation. In the third equation of Equation (2), a plus sign is used to ensure the step is in the opposite direction of the gradient of the error with respect to the coefficients. The adaptive LMS algorithm is shown in Figure 5. Figure 5.
Block diagram of the least-mean-square (LMS) adaptive algorithm.

The LMS adaptive algorithm, as an iterative gradient-descent algorithm, uses an estimate of the gradient on the mean-square error surface to seek the optimum weight vector at the minimum mean-square error point. The term exk represents the estimate of the negative gradient, and the adaptation constant μ determines the step size taken at each iteration along the estimated negative gradient direction. The true negative gradient is given by the expected value of exk. If μ is chosen properly such that small steps are taken, adaptation noise due to error in the gradient estimate is averaged out. When adapting with the adaptive algorithm on stationary stochastic processes, the expected value of the weight vector converges to a Wiener optimal solution (Widrow and Stearns, 1985). The algorithm does not require off-line gradient estimations or repetitions of data.

The adjustment of the adaptive LMS algorithm is directly proportional to the input vector x(k). Therefore, when x(k) is large, the algorithm will suffer from a gradient noise amplification problem. An important limitation regarding the adaptive LMS algorithm is that the selection of a certain value for the step size implies a compromise between the rate of convergence and final misadjustment (Simon, 2002). What is more, the initial value of the weight vector can influence its convergence rate. In a real application, it is usually difficult to determine the step size and the weight initial values such that they are suitable to obtain good convergence performance.

The normalized LMS adaptive algorithm can be used to avoid those difficulties. In particular, the adjustment applied to the weight vector at iteration k+1 is ‘normalized’ with respect to the squared Euclidean norm of the input vector x(k) at iteration k, hence the term is ‘normalized’ (Simon, 2002). In structure terms, the normalized LMS adaptive algorithm, shown in Figure 6, is built around a transversal filter. Figure 6.
Block diagram of the adaptive transversal filter.
The weight updation of the normalized LMS adaptive algorithm is (3)w(k+1)=w(k)+α‖x(k)‖2+δx(k)e(k) where δ>0 is used to overcome the problem of dividing by a small value for the squared norm ‖x(k)‖2.

sec.title: 4. Harmonic identification algorithm
sec.p: From Figures 3 and 4, we can see that there are higher harmonics in the shaking table acceleration response. The system sine acceleration response can be assumed to comprise fundamental and harmonic components as (4)a(t)=∑i=1NAisin(iωt+ϕi) where Ai and ϕi are the amplitude and phase of the harmonics, respectively; N is the total number of harmonics; and ω is the angular frequency of the input acceleration signal. Equation (4) can be written in the discrete form as (5)a=A1(cosϕ1sinωt+sinϕ1cosωt)+…+AN(cosϕNsinNωt+sinϕNcosNωt) where t=kTs. k is the sample number and Ts is the sample time. The task of harmonic identification is to compute the values of Ai and ϕi. To obtain the input vector and the weight vector for the normalized LMS adaptive algorithm, Equation (5) is rewritten as (6)a=w1sinωt+w2cosωt+…+w2N-1sinNωt+w2NcosNωt where w1=A1cosϕ1, w2=A1sinϕ1, … , w2N-1=ANcosϕN, w2N=ANsinϕN. According to the structure of the normalized LMS adaptive algorithm, the input vector is defined as (7)x(k)=[sinωtcosωtsin2ωtcos2ωt…sinNωtcosNωt]T and the weight vector is defined as (8)w(k)=[w1(k)w2(k)…w2N(k)]T

The harmonic identification configuration is shown in Figure 7. The sine acceleration response is used as the desired signal, and the block of the reference harmonics generates the input vector. The error signal e(k) between the actual acceleration signal and the estimated signalais used to drive the adaptive algorithm. Clearly, when the estimated output closely matches the system output, the matching error will be quite small. So training is the process of tuning the weights so that their output matches the desired outcome. Figure 7.
Block diagram of the acceleration harmonic identification.

The error is brought down to zero when perfect learning is attained and the weight vector will yield the Fourier coefficients of the signal. What is more, the estimated output is not zero, but rather stops adapting and should in theory be closely matched to the system output. If w0 is the weight vector after the convergence is reached, the amplitude and phase of the ith harmonic are given by (9)Ai=w0,2i-12+w0,2i2 and (10)ϕi=tan-1w0,2iw0,2i-1
From Equation (10), the phase is the result of dividing by the adjacent weights. This may lead to noise amplification, so it is necessary to filter out the noise amplification.

sec.title: 5. Experimental results
sec.p:
The harmonic identification scheme shown in Figure 7 is used to estimate the acceleration harmonics of the electro-hydraulic servo shaking table and is operated on the target computer. From Figure 3, there are fivehigher harmonics, so the input vector is x(k)=[sinωtcosωtsin2ωtcos2ωt…sin6ωtcos6ωt]T and the length of the weight vector is 12. α=0.05, δ=10-6, and the initial values of the weights are allset to zero. The estimation results are shown in Figure 8. Table 4 is computed averagely in the steady state of Figure 8. From Figure 8(a) and Table 4, we can see that the amplitude of each harmonic including the fundamental response is very close to the value in Table 2, especially the basic response, second, third and fourth harmonics. The identified phase of the basic response is zero. This is true, because the input acceleration signal phase is also zero. The curve of the phase of the second harmonic and the third harmonic are straight with little variation, while the following three harmonic phases drift around a nominal value, especially the sixth harmonic. sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: An acceleration harmonic identification algorithm has been developed by using the normalized LMS adaptive algorithm for the sine acceleration response of an electro-hydraulic servo shaking table. The amplitude and phase of each acceleration harmonic are computed from the weight vector of the normalized LMS adaptive algorithm. The results thus presented here can be used to provide a basis for harmonic cancellation.

Although most frequency domain harmonic analysis techniques use discrete Fourier transform (DFT) or FFT, which are used to transform samples of time domain into the frequency domain, the phenomena of aliasing, leakage and picket fence effects may lead to inaccurate estimation of harmonic magnitudes, and the DFT suffers from inaccuracies due to the presence of random noise that is usual in the measurement process and tracking of signals with time-varying amplitude and phases involving large errors. The developed identification scheme was validated by comparing with the values computed by FFT. However, the FFT algorithm is operated off-line. The proposed algorithm can estimate harmonics on-line, thus has good real-time performance.

The parameters of the normalized LMS adaptive algorithm are easy to determine, and have little influence on the convergence rate. The performance of the identification algorithm is superior for its good learning ability, high real-time performance and high speed recognition, because it is adaptive and capable of tracking the variations of amplitude and phase angle of the harmonics. Its structure is simple and is easy to realize, and it does not need to know the a priori knowledge of the system.

The identification algorithm can decompose each order of harmonic and detect the amplitude and phase of any order of harmonic, as well as the fundamental wave in the same time. From the estimation results, it can be seen that the identification precision of amplitude is better than that of phase, and the estimation result becomes worse for the harmonics that are in the least dominance among all harmonics, for example, the fifth and sixth harmonics in Figure 8 and the fourth and fifth harmonics in Figure 10, especially for the estimation of the harmonic phase. From the viewpoint of harmonic cancellation, cancellation of harmonics in dominance can greatly reduce the THD, so the estimation precision of those harmonics is essential.
